Fixed in #329 

Now the output looks as 

```
usage: heron <command> <options> ...

Available commands:
    activate           Activate a topology
    deactivate         Deactivate a topology
    help               Prints help for commands
    kill               Kill a topology
    restart            Restart a topology
    submit             Submit a topology
    version            Print version of heron-cli

Getting more help: 
  heron help <command> Prints help and options for <command>

For detailed documentation, go to http://heronstreaming.io
```
Reopening to also address the heron-cli documentation inconsistencies in my second comment.

I'm a fan of excluding 'we' and 'us' as well - this was just continuing to follow the Bazel community as a guide: http://bazel.io/contributing.html (note nav bar 'community' is also following Bazel), thanks.

No need to follow the bazel docs that closely. We can change it to be more neutral.

> In general, contributions that fix bugs or add features (as opposed to stylistic, refactoring, or "cleanup" changes) are preferred. Please check on the dev list (heron-dev@googlegroups.com) before investing a lot of time in a patch.

Looks good.
What's the process for updating the semver version when cutting a release? Where does that info get set/stored?

@billonahill - the release process generates a file called RELEASE and this file is included in all of the tarballs and packages. heron cli reads from this RELEASE to display the information. Similarly we will make other components to read this as well - for any version checks.
What is the release process and how do we set the semver version?

```
import com.twitter.heron.api.generated.TopologyAPI;
```

Discussed within the team, and decided to just document it down (Solution 3). Will re-consider to solve this issue in future when it is really needed.

okay, finally figured out the library setting that's been bugging me for days. this one should be completely hands off. the latest commits include the following:
1. library settings that include heron-proto and thrift in the module libraries - so we should really have a clean workspace with zero errors
2. Project SDK inclusion 
3. src folder exclusion if there is a xxBUILD file. if we need to re-enable , this requires to run setup intellij

steps to verify - 
cd heron-root
rm -rf .idea *.iml
cd scripts
./setup-intellij.sh
cd ..
open intellij project in idea
project -> Make

there should be zero compilation errors - see screenshot below

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4031715/14508318/b80c4c12-017b-11e6-89a9-a0c1c6a6ee77.png)
@billonahill @kramasamy any additional comments on this updated PR, removing 'we/us' language and addressing 'heron architecture' comment?  thanks!
We should discuss building the docs in README.rb or website/README.rb but not both. This latest commit seems to keep the latter file in place.

Thanks looks good, thanks! I still can't create a file under the top level project dir, but that's not a big deal.

+1
üëç

This includes changes in the SPI. Won't this break existing scheduler code?

If yes, we probably should keep the existing SPI, and add new interfaces for serial calls. OR we break the SPI this time and communicate to others.

In either case, may we should keep the async version around as well.

@saileshmittal 
Hi,

You are right, changing SPI is possible to break existing scheduler code.
But consider these:
1. From the start of design, we decided to make all calls in SchedulerStateManagerAdaptor synchronized  and there might be some miscommunications or other unknown reasons, it is in async style, which is hard to reason and use in Scheduler implementation case.
2. I checked current scheduler implementations in the repo and fixed the breaking parts. Async interfaces may not be a good idea in SchedulerStateManagerAdaptor: IStateManager is fully async, and we could expose IStateManager from SchedulerStateManagerAdaptor if in future async methods are really needed.
Consider we are still in an early stage, it is ok to break things rather than keep async version for backward compatibility concern (which may not even exist at current stage).
ok üëç

@prabhuinbarajan I've found that any files that aren't under 3rdparty or heron are not recognized as being project filed. This means you get a warning when editing them and their git changes don't appear. I think we want the top level dir to be a content root.

Thanks, @billonahill !  I had problems with the new build make, so enclosing <!-- --> didn't appear to work in the md, but testing this now it works, thanks for the pointer!  The committers/contributors list we discussed Sunday, potentially adding company affiliation if possible, to encourage a growing OSS community, hopefully we revisit a list. @ashvina - can you review this - since you will have some impact?

Thanks @lewiskan but I think I've gotten most taken care of now. I forgot to link to this ticket. What's remaining is the following:
- Getting javadocs built and fixing those links (#347)
- Getting user documentation committed and fixing those links (#346)

Then a few other items like getting linkchecker to run as part of the site release (#349) and integrating java style checking (#348).

Let me know if any of these are in your wheelhouse. I'm working on the javadocs ticket with @lucperkins. You can see other issues we need to complete at milestone v0.13.3:
https://github.com/twitter/heron/milestones/v0.13.3
@billonahill @kramasamy - I can take a shot at this, 'pip install linkchecker' worked, then add a check when pushing to gh-pages for publication.

Great. I was thinking the we could build the site via the website/makefile for now as described here:
https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/355/files

then we publish website/public to a github subtree like this:
https://gohugo.io/tutorials/github-pages-blog/

but open for other suggestions.

Yes, we are on the same page - as a test and in order to keep the site private, I re-created the heron structure and used 'hugo build' to generate the static site, pushing to branch 'gh-pages' following the github-pages-blog outline.  Here's the sample:

http://lewiskan.github.io/hackprojectorg/website/public/
(redirected from 'hackproject.org')

linkchecker appears to allow checking static pages via:

```
Checking local HTML files on Unix:
  linkchecker ../bla.html subdir/blubber.html
```

(mac osx, unix only however).  This avoids needing to host the site locally using 'hugo server --watch', seeing if there is an easy way to get github to force this check prior to pushing to gh-pages specifically, any suggestions greatly appreciated!

Yeah, I went through the same exercise with gh-pages. :) We already have a branch with a placeholder:
http://billonahill.github.io/heron/
http://twtiter.github.io/heron/

If we could run linkchecker on the files on disk without the hugo server that would be awesome. For now if we get the publish to website/public working with link checking we're good. We can add/update the subtree when we're ready to go live.

I don't think we need github to do the check, since re-publishing the website will probably be a manual process when we cut a release. Still, it should be as automated as possible.

Awesome!  We were careful not to publish anything hinting at a Heron open source release so I removed any reference to Heron.  The Twitter link should be discovered soon, similar to the Apache Heron proposal and tweeted, but we are closer to launch.

MakeFile added publish:
publish:
    @hugo
    @pip install linkchecker
    @linkchecker public/index.html 

NOTE: this works on Mac but unsure on Windows/Linux.  Command result that I'm investingating: 
make: **\* [publish] Error 1

README instructions:
To publish website using github pages (requires python pip)

``` bash
$ make publish
```

If linkchecker errors are 0, then publish to branch gh-pages

``` bash
$ git checkout -b gh-pages
$ git push origin gh-pages
```

Submit PR to main branch gh-pages (not master)

PR #355 added the javadoc build target. What's left is to integrate that with website/make and then fix the broken links listed above. Reassigning to @lucperkins who's kindly offered to help with that part.

+1 works for me too.

I have one observation. I have used maven eclipse plugin in the past to
generate project files from existing source. It is very fast and existence
of java compilation errors does not fail creation of project files. When
used for the first time the intellij script for Heron takes a very long
time and fails if there are compilation errors. Is it possible to avoid
code compilation for generating IDE files?

Thanks,
Ashvin

@prabhuinbarajan and @maosongfu try working on files that aren't below `heron/` or `3rdparty/`. They're unrecognized, which causes all sorts of problems. They need to be part of a content root.

Editing a file show's it's not recognized in the project:
![non-project_files_access_and_build-artifacts sh_-_heron_-____ws_git_heron_](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/23758/14570774/ceb86a74-02fa-11e6-9203-c630af9e157f.png)

You can't see git history:
![build-artifacts sh_-_heron_-____ws_git_heron_-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/23758/14570845/1e04bbc8-02fb-11e6-8904-92768a85b395.png)

You can't add new files:
![build-artifacts sh_-_heron_-____ws_git_heron_](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/23758/14570857/378117a4-02fb-11e6-9444-6eb5b0d2f3c1.png)

@lewiskan Do you mean the Compilation fails when enabling some options? We can compile it sucessfully.

Hi @maosongfu - @kramasamy  merged this fix into master.  The compilation using bazel 0.2.0-homebrew failed on my machine after running:

```
$ bazel build --config=darwin heron/...
```

(note no options)
with error described in issue.  Following the error suggestion in 3 files fixed the compilation issue, and all travis-ci tests pass.  This issue should be closed, thanks!
This looks good to me.
